xxl.core.cursors.differences

Class NestedLoopsDifference<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      • xxl.core.cursors.differences.NestedLoopsDifference<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the elements returned by this difference.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    NestedLoopsDifference

    public class NestedLoopsDifference<E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>
    A nested-loops implementation of the difference operator (input1 - input2). This operation can be performed in two different ways, namely the first realization removes an element of input1 if the same element exists in input2. The second way of processing removes all elements of input1 that match with an element of input2. This second approch implies that no duplicates will be returned by the difference operator, whereas the first solution may contain duplicates if the number of equal elements in cursor input1 is greater than that of input2.

    The difference operator implemented by this class supports realization depending on a boolean flag all that signals if all elements of cursor input1 that fulfill the given predicate will be removed or only one element will be removed. As mentioned above a predicate is used to determine if an element of input2 matches with an element of input1. If no predicate has been specified, internally the equality predicate is used by default. The function newBag generates an empty bag each time it is invoked. This bag should reside in main memory and contains as much elements of input1 as possible. Each element of input2 gets checked for a match with an element contained in this bag. The size of the bag depends on the specified arguments memSize and objectSize. The maximum number of elements this bag is able to contain is computed by the formula:

       maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1
    One element is subtracted due to the reason that a minimum of one element of cursor input2 has also to be located in main memory.

    Example usage (1): 

       NestedLoopsDifference<Integer> difference = new NestedLoopsDifference<Integer>(
       new Enumerator(21),
       new Filter<Integer>(
           new Enumerator(21),
           new Predicate<Integer>() {
               public boolean invoke(Integer next) {
                   return next % 2 == 0;
               }
           }
       ),
       32,
       8,
       Bag.FACTORY_METHOD,
       new Predicate<Integer>() {
           public boolean invoke(Integer previous, Integer next) {
               return previous == next;
           }
       },
       false
   );
   
   difference.open();
   
   while (difference.hasNext())
       System.out.println(difference.next());
       
   difference.close();
    This nested-loops difference substracts all even numbers contained in the interval [0, 21) from all numbers of the same interval (input1). The available mememory size is set to 32 bytes and an object has the size of 8 bytes. So a maximum of 3 elements can be stored in the temporal main memory bag. The FACTORY_METHOD of the class Bag delivers a new empty bag, therefore a list-bag will be used to store the elements of cursor input1. The specified predicate returns true if an element of input1 and an element of input2 are equal in their integer values. In this example the flag all can be specified arbitrary due to input1 contains no duplicates. But if the first input cursor would contain all elements from 0 to 20 twice the result would be the same.

    Example usage (2): 

       difference = new NestedLoopsDifference<Integer>(
       Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3, 4).iterator(),
       Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3).iterator(),
       32,
       8,
       new Function<Object, Iterator<Integer>>() {
           public Iterator<Integer> invoke() {
               return Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3).iterator();
           }
       },
       false
   );
   
   difference.open();
   
   while (difference.hasNext())
       System.out.println(difference.next());
   
   difference.close();
    This example computes the difference between to iterators based on the lists {1, 2, 2, 3} and {1, 2, 3}. The memory usage is equal to that in example 1, but in this case the flag all leads to different results.
    • If all == true this operator delivers no results, because each element of input2 is equal to an element of input1.
    • But if all == false the element '2' is returned because it is only substracted once from input1.
    The function specified above resets and returns the input cursor input2, because it supports no reset operation, but has to be traversed several times (inner loop). The predicate comparing two elements concerning equality is set to Equal.DEFAULT_INSTANCE by default.

    Note: If an input iteration is given by an object of the class Iterator, i.e., it does not support the peek operation, it is internally wrapped to a cursor.

    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, Function, Predicate, Equal, Bag, SortBasedDifference, NestedLoopsDifference

      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected boolean all
      A flag signaling if all matches or only one matche returned by the predicate should be removed from the internal bag.
      protected Cursor<E> input1
      The first (or left) input cursor of the difference operator.

      The second (or right) input cursor of the difference operator.
      protected int maxTuples
      The maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag returned by the function newBag.
      protected Function<?,? extends Bag<E>> newBag
      A parameterless function returning a new bag on demand.

      The predicate used to determine a match between an element of input2 and an element of input1.
      protected BitSet removedElements
      A bit set storing which elements of cursor input2 have been removed from cursor input1 already.
      protected Function<?,? extends Cursor<? extends E>> resetInput2
      A parameterless function used to reset and return the second input cursor.
      protected Cursor<E> results
      The output cursor of the difference operator.

    • Constructor Detail

      • NestedLoopsDifference

        public NestedLoopsDifference(Iterator<E> input1,
                             Iterator<? extends E> input2,
                             int memSize,
                             int objectSize,
                             Function<?,? extends Bag<E>> newBag,
                             Function<?,? extends Iterator<? extends E>> resetInput2,
                             Predicate<? super E> predicate,
                             boolean all)
        Creates a new instance of the nested-loops difference operator. Every input iterator is wrapped to a cursor. Determines the maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag used for the temporal storage of the elements of input1 in main memory: 
             maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1
        This constructor should only be used if cursor input2 is not resetable.
        Parameters:
        input1 - the first input iterator where the elements have to be subtracted from.
        input2 - the second input iterator containing the elements that have to be subtracted.
        memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory that can be used for the bag.
        objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one object of an input cursor.
        newBag - a parameterless function delivering an empty bag on demand. This bag is used to store the elements of cursor input1.
        resetInput2 - a parameterless function that delivers the second input cursor again. This constructor should only be used if the second input cursor does not support the reset functionality.
        predicate - a binaray predicate that has to determine a match between an element of input1 and an element of input2.
        all - a boolean flag signaling if all elements contained in the bag that have a positiv match concerning the predicate will be removed or only one element will be removed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.

      • NestedLoopsDifference

        public NestedLoopsDifference(Iterator<E> input1,
                             Iterator<? extends E> input2,
                             int memSize,
                             int objectSize,
                             Function<?,? extends Iterator<? extends E>> resetInput2,
                             boolean all)
        Creates a new instance of the nested-loops difference operator. Every input iterator is wrapped to a cursor. Determines the maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag used for the temporal storage of the elements of input1 in main memory: 
             maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1
        Uses the factory method for bags, Bag.FACTORY_METHOD. Determines the equality between an element of input1 and input2 with the help of the default instance of the equality predicate. This constructor should only be used if cursor input2 is not resetable.
        Parameters:
        input1 - the first input iterator where the elements have to be subtracted from.
        input2 - the second input iterator containing the elements that have to be subtracted.
        memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory that can be used for the bag.
        objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one object of an input cursor.
        resetInput2 - a parameterless function that delivers the second input cursor again. This constructor should only be used if the second input cursor does not support the reset functionality.
        all - a boolean flag signaling if all elements contained in the bag that have a positiv match concerning the predicate will be removed or only one element will be removed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.

      • NestedLoopsDifference

        public NestedLoopsDifference(Iterator<E> input1,
                             Cursor<? extends E> input2,
                             int memSize,
                             int objectSize,
                             Function<?,? extends Bag<E>> newBag,

             maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1
        Input2 has to support the reset operation, otherwise an UnsupportedOperationException will be thrown!
        Parameters:

        memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory that can be used for the bag.

        public NestedLoopsDifference(Iterator<E> input1,
                             Cursor<? extends E> input2,
                             int memSize,
                             int objectSize,
                             boolean all)
        Creates a new instance of the nested-loops difference operator. Every input iterator is wrapped to a cursor. Determines the maximum number of elements that can be stored in the bag used for the temporal storage of the elements of input1 in main memory: 
             maxTuples = memSize / objectSize - 1
        Uses the factory method for bags, Bag.FACTORY_METHOD. Determines the equality between an element of input1 and input2 with the help of the default instance of the equality predicate. Input2 has to support the reset operation, otherwise an UnsupportedOperationException will be thrown!
        Parameters:
        input1 - the first input iterator where the elements have to be subtracted from.
        input2 - the second input iterator containing the elements that have to be subtracted.
        memSize - the maximum amount of available main memory that can be used for the bag.
        objectSize - the size (bytes) needed to store one object of an input cursor.
        all - a boolean flag signaling if all elements contained in the bag that have a positiv match concerning the predicate will be removed or only one element will be removed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if not enough main memory is available.

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the nested-loops difference operator, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open input iterations, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

        Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        open in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the nested-loops difference operator, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources and close its input and output cursors. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

        Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

        Builds a temporal bag calling newBag.invoke() and stores as much elements of cursor input1 in this bag as possible. After that each element of the second input cursor is taken and with the help of the bag's query method a cursor containing all elements that have to be removed from input1 are determined. Depending on the flag all all elements contained in that cursor are removed from the bag or only one element is removed. At last the bag's cursor method is called and the result cursor's reference is set to this cursor. If the result cursor contains any elements, true is returned, otherwise false. If the cursor input1 contains further elements the whole procedure is returned.

        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the nested-loops difference operator has more elements.

      • nextObject

        protected E nextObject()
        Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be removed from the iteration, if next is called. This method returns the next element of the result cursor and removes it from the underlying bag.
        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.

      • remove

        public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
        Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the nested-loops difference operator (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and removes the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and remove the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method. This method is only supported if the bag's size is limited to only one element, otherwise an UnsupportedOperationException will be thrown.
        Specified by:
        remove in interface Iterator<E>
        Specified by:
        remove in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        remove in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the nested-loops difference operator, i.e., thebag's size is greater than 1.

      • supportsRemove

        public boolean supportsRemove()
        Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the nested-loops difference operator. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsRemove in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        supportsRemove in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the remove operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

      • update

        public void update(E object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
        Replaces the object that was returned by the last call to next or peek (optional operation). This operation must not be called after a call to hasNext. It should follow a call to next or peek. This method should be called only once per call to next or peek. The behaviour of a nested-loops difference operator is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method. This method is only supported if the bag's size is limited to only one element, otherwise an UnsupportedOperationException will be thrown.
        Specified by:
        update in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        update in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Parameters:
        object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by the nested-loops difference operator, i.e., the bag's size is greater than 1.

      • supportsUpdate

        public boolean supportsUpdate()
        Returns true if the update operation is supported by the nested-loops difference operator. Otherwise it returns false.

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Resets the nested-loops difference operator to its initial state (optional operation). So the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again. The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent. This method resets the input cursors, closes the result cursor and sets it to null.
        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the nested-loops difference operator.
